messages.text: SafeHaven chat. 02/06/17 5:13 PM.
Dr. Took is connected.
Mr. Hewitt, I am a therapist under your management at SafeHaven. We haven't talked before but I need to speak to you now.
It's an emergency.
Lyle Hewitt is connected.
Hello, Dr. Took. How may I assist you?
I have a patient who has expressed intent to kill his brother.
He said he has a plan and there's a gun in the house.
His username is patientzero.
That's troubling, indeed. How can I help?
I have a duty to warn his brother, but the patient has chosen to remain anonymous.
I need his information so I can fulfill my legal obligation to report.
If he has chosen to remain anonymous, I cannot help you.
Don't you have his personal information?
We require only a username, an email address, and a valid credit card.
How am I supposed to proceed without his name or address?
You may urge him to call 911 or go to his nearest emergency room.
I have encouraged him to contact the authorities and he has refused several times.
I need to locate his brother.
I'm afraid I can't help you.
I cannot release his email address or payment information to you.
Why not?
We have a strict code of confidentiality here at SafeHaven.
And I have a duty to break confidentiality when someone's life is in danger.
Regardless, I don't have your customer's identifying information.
Isn't it negligent to treat someone without the proper paperwork?
You provide the treatment, Dr. Took. We merely provide the platform for your services.
Remember, you are an independent freelancer and not a SafeHaven employee.
It is up to you to collect the necessary patient information at your discretion.
The service agreement that users sign when they register with SafeHaven specifically states that users may remain anonymous.
The patient did not choose to offer his personal information to me. I've asked for it several times.
I did all I could.
I'm sorry.
This is a serious issue, Mr. Hewitt. I need something to go on.
Could you provide me with his IP address?
Dr. Took, if you continue to press me for confidential customer information, I will be forced to put your status as an active therapist with SafeHaven under review.
He's not a customerâ€”he's my patient.
I have every right to his information, particularly in emergency circumstances such as these.
He is volatile and emotionally unstable.
He thinks his brother is a threat.
Well, is he?
I don't know. I haven't treated his brother.
His fears may be legitimate or may be a manifestation of his paranoia.
You have to tell me his information.
Absolutely not.
This is bullshit.
You are perilously close to insubordination, Dr. Took.
We take our customer's privacy very seriously.
I take homicide very seriously, Mr. Hewitt.
I believe this patient to be mentally ill and he is in crisis.
He may need to be hospitalized.
Or does management not actually care about the patients?
Is this just a business to you, with customers and credit cards? Is it all about profit to you?
Should you continue this tirade, Dr. Took, I will be forced to temporarily suspend your access to the platform.
How will I treat my patients without access?
You won't. They will be transferred to another SafeHaven therapist.
So what do you recommend I do in this situation, Mr. Hewitt?
I recommend you show management some respect and continue to provide treatment to the customer.
Should you suspect any evidence of danger, advise him to reach out to law enforcement or go to the emergency room of his choice.
Is that my only option?
Should you wish to maintain access to the customer, yes.
There's one additional issue I'd like to discuss with you at this time.
Fine.
I strongly advise you to focus your efforts on retaining your customers, Dr. Took.
A high rate of attrition reflects poorly on our therapists.
Excuse me?
You have lost two customers this month.
Those two patients had minor situational issues that were resolved in our sessions.
They did not require further treatment.
I believe it would be unethical to coax a patient into continued treatment when they feel satisfied with our work and their sense of stability.
I see you also declined to treat a patient about three months ago. You advised him to seek out a traditional, in-office therapist.
You went so far as to provide him with referrals in his area.
That patient had a chronic mental health issue. He needed more help than I could offer via text.
Like patientzero. I feel he is a serious risk to his brother, and perhaps himself or others.
I thought text therapy might work well for him initially due to his need for anonymity.
But by our second exchange it became clear to me that he needs a higher level of care.
Should I tell him to seek in-person treatment, however, I think he'd refuse and stop treatment with me, too.
You are under direct orders not to recommend other treatments to patientzero unless they are supplemental to his treatment here.
If you lose him as a customer, consider your access to SafeHaven permanently revoked.
This isn't about customers and retention. These are two men's lives at stake.
He is your responsibility, Dr. Took.
Keep an eye on your attrition rates. I know I will.
Mr. Hewitt, wait.
I'll be in touch soon regarding your performance review.
I expect to see some improvement, Dr. Took.
Please, Mr. Hewitt.
Take care.
Wait.
Please.
Mr. Hewitt?
Lyle Hewitt is disconnected.
